Award.AwardTitle: Understanding estuarine carbon cycling within the context of climatic and anthropogenic change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Estuaries are among the most productive ecosystems on Earth, but are affected negatively by a wide array of interacting human and climatic stressors, including nutrient over-enrichment, climate warming, and changes in the amount of freshwater input. The investigators seek to understand the cumulative effect of these stressors through additions to and synthesis of a long-term water-quality database for the Neuse River Estuary (NRE) in North Carolina, a representative coastal-plain estuary with a growing human population in its watershed. The NRE is experiencing increases in nutrient loading, frequency of tropical cyclones, and climatic extremes. Nutrient and carbon-cycle measurements, including CO2 exchange and microalgal (phytoplankton) production, will be collected and studied for trends and patterns of variability that link to specific stressors. It is hypothesized that regional climate patterns modulate the impacts of management efforts, thus masking potential recovery in the NRE.

Shared project data and results will help researchers, managers, and decision makers to better predict and adaptively manage water quality of estuarine ecosystems under the influence of human and climatic changes. The project will provide diverse educational and employment opportunities for post-doctoral researchers and students at the graduate, undergraduate (including those enrolled in a companion NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates program), and high-school levels. Web-based summaries and classroom exercises will enhance K-12 science curricula and inform the public on local estuarine water-quality issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, which was focused on the Neuse River Estuary, NC showed that a significant, non-linear relationship exists between a key indicator of phytoplankton, chlorophyll a, and fresh water flushing time, which relates to residence time. Phytoplankton biomass, as estimated by chlorophyll a, increases rapidly with flushing time to a maximum at flushing times of about two weeks and decreases more slowly as flushing times continue to increase. When the biomass is separated into different taxonomic groups using algal photopigments, the flushing time relationships diverged and some taxa achieved maximum biomass at flushing times longer than 10 days. These results demonstrate the complex role hydrologic forcing plays on estuarine phytoplankton production and community composition by being both a source of nutrients and at times a limit on growth through advection.

Estimates of fluxes of the greenhouse gas, CO2,  to and from the Neuse River estuary continued to be refined during this project. pCO2 showed significant departures from equilibrium with the atmosphere (~400 µatm) and exhibited a large dynamic range, from 28 to 6275 µatm. Overall, when scaled to a full year, the Neuse River estuary had an average CO2 flux to the atmosphere of 8.0 mmol C m-2 d-1. This rate is significantly lower than previous literature estimates for other estuaries worldwide, but is similar to what has been noted in the Neuse (and New) River estuary previously and to other lagoonal or microtidal systems. During the study period, the upper estuary was a large source of CO2 to the atmosphere (80.7 mmol C m-2 d-1), while the middle and lower segments were both small sources or sinks for CO2 from the atmosphere (10.2 and 1.5 mmol C m-2 d-1 respectively). Generally, CO2 fluxes were governed by the interactions between river discharge, temperature, and wind. Maximum CO2 fluxes were seen during conditions of elevated river discharge and during the passage of a prolonged storm system, while maximum uptake was observed under moderate river discharge, and when waters were relatively cool and productive. These project results illustrate the potential for large temporal and spatial variability in estuarine CO2 fluxes, and will provide valuable supporting information for regional and global C budget improvements.

The project results fill a critical part of the long-term estuarine database that now extends beyond 20 years, a time frame that is necessary for detecting ecosystem changes in the context of multiple stressors. Project personnel developed a lesson plan that utilized project data for K-12 science teachers as part of the Scientific Research and Education Network (SciREN) Coast 2016 Event. See also the publications and presentations that communicated project results and achievements in the accompanying final report.
